content: Is there a proof in mathlib for something like "If the nth derivative of f(x) is zero on (a, b) for some n, then f(x) is a polynomial on (a, b)"?

As it stands, this statement isn't true, because nondifferentiable functions have junk values for derivatives and these junk values are 0. But if you add in the assumption that the function is C^n then it should be ok :-) While you're waiting for an answer, you could try formalising the statement in lean and then ask exact?
Loogle finds nothing. It should be easy to prove by induction. Please PR it!

It might (I’m not sure) be easier to prove that the result holds if some n’th derivative is a polynomial on your interval, for which your result would be a special case anyway. (I’d expect the induction step to be a bit easier there)
I guess, the right statement is "if n-th derivative is a polynomial of degree k, then the function is a polynomial of degree n + k), provable by induction on n generalizing k.
Thanks, everyone - I'll see if I can come up with a proof and pr it
This looks like it could be true for Polynomial.degree except that you want bot + 1 to be 0 :-/
yeah, kind of, but it's not literally true in WithBot \N which is what docs#Polynomial.degree is taking values in...

I guess the claim above is simply not true for 0; if the n'th derivative has degree bot (i.e. is 0) then all we know is that the original function is a poly of degree < n (as opposed to knowing the degree on the nose). So perhaps the thing to prove is that if the n'th derivative is a poly of degree < (k : Nat) then the function is a poly of degree < (n + k) (here degree means docs#Polynomial.degree)

oh, wait, there's already something very similar for the polynomial formal derivative: https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Algebra/Polynomial/Derivative.html#Polynomial.natDegree_iterate_derivative
so, combining this with https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Analysis/Calculus/Deriv/Polynomial.html#Polynomial.deriv should give me what I need
Aaron Hill has marked this topic as resolved.
(If it is missing, you may want to add a specialized result for if the derivative is 0)
